Award.AwardTitle: MATH:EAGER Understanding faculty barriers in adopting evidence-based integrated mathematics curricula

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Successful experiences in mathematics during the first two years of college are critical to students' persistence and learning in engineering. There is a need within engineering to examine courses in the engineering program in order to both provide appropriate learning experiences that increase students' knowledge and retention of content and support their persistence in engineering. This project will address this with an integrated mathematics and engineering course that connects the mathematics students need to engineering tasks and contexts. The goal of the project is to explore an engineering mathematics course designed within the college of engineering. The first objective is to design and teach the course while collecting data about students' performance, persistence and their mathematics understanding. The second objective is to investigate faculty perceptions of students' knowledge of mathematics to understand the structural barriers that may prevent the adoption of such a course. The EHR Core Research program, which supports this work, emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

The integrated engineering and mathematics course is important for supporting students' learning and application of knowledge from mathematics within engineering. Each mathematics topic in the course will include an engineering perspective and tasks. The project will specifically investigate the perception of students' mathematical maturity by mathematics faculty. The research design includes a case study of the mathematics department using interviews with faculty and students as well as the collection of other documents that describe the context. The case study data will also include clinical interviews with students from the engineering mathematics course and a comparable course to document their mathematical understanding and beliefs.

ProgramReference.Text: Math Success in First 2 Years of College

POR.DRECONTENT:
Efforts to train, expand, and diversify the engineering workforce are often thwarted by students? preparation and performance in mathematics courses. As many as a third of students leave engineering degrees before they even take an engineering course because they fail these mathematics courses. Other students struggle in their engineering courses because they fail to apply knowledge from their mathematics courses in their engineering courses. Unfortunately, the requirements for students to take these prerequisite mathematics courses is largely taken for granted without their necessity or value being critically examined. If we are requiring students to learn mathematical content knowledge that is unnecessary or could be delayed to improve knowledge transfer, then we may be able to identify potential systemic changes that may both increase how many future engineers we train and improve how well those engineers are able to apply mathematics in their engineering practice. In this study, we interviewed engineering professors from a majority of engineering sub-disciplines to better understand what mathematics knowledge they believe is essential for students to excel in engineering. We concurrently analyzed homework assignments from introductory engineering courses to document what mathematics knowledge is needed in these courses. Results from these research studies can be used to facilitate dialogue between engineering and mathematics departments to determine the best sequence of courses and content to help the most students succeed in their engineering coursework.

Our research revealed that engineering professors believe that successful mathematics preparation should primarily train engineering students on how to use mathematics to reason about engineering systems. These professors talked about how it is vital for engineering students to learn about physical or information systems and then be able to describe those systems using the language of mathematics. Likewise, engineering students should be able to look at mathematical descriptions of systems and be able to interpret them to extract information about those systems to inform their decision making. Similarly, engineering professors emphasized that their students needed to learn how to use the mathematical symbols and representations that best communicate their ideas. Altogether, these findings reveal that engineering professors were primarily concerned that their students could use mathematics as a language and tool for communication and were less concerned that students would be able to solve specific or complex mathematical problems. Many professors further emphasized this point by arguing that advances in computing technology mean that mathematics problems can be solved faster and more reliably using the appropriate computational tools rather than being able to solve those same problems by hand. However, in order to choose and use the best computational tools, students need to know how to make sense of the mathematics they need to use. Many professors emphasized that they were more concerned that students had a solid grounding in algebra, trigonometry, and geometry and were less concerned about students? ability to apply calculus knowledge early in their engineering curriculum. These findings were corroborated by our analysis of engineering homework assignments, where as few as 10% of problems in introductory engineering courses required any knowledge of calculus. Most engineering problems relied primarily on students? knowledge of algebra instead. 

Our findings suggest that there may be many possible productive avenues for improving outcomes for engineering students by re-considering how we design engineering curriculum. Most engineering curricula require students to take several calculus courses before being able to take their engineering coursework. It is likely that these curricula may not be serving students? nor the engineering professors? needs well. Future work will need to explore whether moving calculus instruction later in the engineering curriculum may improve retention and attainment for engineering students. Alternatively, creating more integrative approaches of teaching mathematics that focus on helping students use mathematics as a language rather than only solving isolated problems may be equally beneficial. By re-imagining how we teach mathematics to engineers, we may train better engineers who in turn will be better able to solve the pressing technological challenges facing our country.
